text: 【3.1.1.0｜Option A: Agree to Her】
“…Alright. I’ll come.”
The words leave my mouth and even I’m startled. Like I’ve just read a line that was written long before I saw the page.
“Mm.”
It’s only a single sound, but she exhales with it. Then quickly swallows that relief and straightens herself.
“What will you make?”
“What do you want to eat?”
Her gaze flickers—like the question touched something soft and dangerous.
“Anything.”
“Just… not too salty.”
She adds quickly, almost tripping over the words:
“Your hand’s still hurt. Don’t force it while cutting. The knife’s in the second drawer. Not the first.”
I look up sharply. I’ve never told her about that drawer.
“How do you even know—”
“Because I don’t want to see you cut yourself again.”
She says it too naturally. Like she’s said it many times before.
She turns to arrange the candles. Her movements are unsettlingly precise: two on the left, one on the right, leaving space in the center for the plate.
I place the salt shaker on the left, just like she expects.
She watches it for two full seconds—like confirming the world has finally aligned the way she wanted, at least once.
“Good.”
That “good” doesn’t sound like it’s about the salt.
The noise from the market outside slowly fades. The tavern is left with only the quiet breathing of the fire.
“Don’t let anyone interrupt us tonight.”
“You’re saying that like—”
“Like nothing. Don’t finish that sentence.”
She looks at me. Her voice softens—but her resolve hardens.
“Just sit there.”
“Stay with me until this meal is over.”
I nod.
Her shoulders finally loosen.
But her fingers still tremble faintly—like she’s fighting against a countdown only she can hear.
